column4: what is the difference between tar -cjvp filename.bz2 file and bzip2 file?
verbosity? :-p
no, because i was doing it for a man page and the man utility will not work with the tar -cvjf

strange... very strange, you probably won't get much help in here though, for more command line oriented things I generally go to #bash (alot of jerks will say it's not a bash question, which it really isn't, but the right people to answer are in there) or ##linux
haha. ya. thanx
but lately i can't get anwsers to my command line questions on any channel. so i got desperate and came here

must be *really* desperate lol, erm, have you checked to see if the first 4 bytes (file header) of the two files is the same? it's possible bzip2 uses a different header I suppose.  also aren't man pages generally gzipped anyways?\
i think the gunzip is old school for man pages. i did the 'file command' and they both said bzip2 files
hrm, is it possible that bzip2 is creating an archive instead of just a bzipped single file? (like a tar.gz vs just a .gz) ?
from what i thought they were both containers and compressed. the only thing i can think of is bzip2 file isn't in a 'container'... even though in reality it is.
have you tried tar -tf <whatever> on both?
no, good idea.
i guess there is a diff. when using or not using tar. although the file utility does not see it
did you figure out what it was?
naw, it has something to do with diff. formats. i'll have to post on the forums to get a more deeper insight on how the 2 versus each other
aw, well good luck dude, at least you have a working method though right? using tar?
ya, for man page it must be done without the tar command(bzip2)
OH  tar *doesn't* work and bzip2 does?
yes, although the man utility rejects a file that is bzip2 with tar

ah, definitely related to container vs not in my opinion (since the tar command implicitly creates a tar container)  the reason why file can't tell the difference is because it would have to decompress each bzip file to see that one contains a tar inside it.  (or at least that's my take)
ya, i was under the impression 'container' was just a generic term for files contained together....which would be the same for any compression like bzip2 without tar
i'm outter here. take care.
later, good luck
